channel.title: Comments on: Ease your plotting with config-snippets

item.title: By: hagen
item.dc:creator: hagen
item.description: Hi, I know this problem, but haven't spend time so far on finding a solution. As a workaround I'm using directly the pngcairo terminal.
item.content:encoded:
Hi,
I know this problem, but haven’t spend time so far on finding a solution. As a workaround I’m using directly the pngcairo terminal.

item.title: By: Pawe?
item.dc:creator: Pawe?
item.description:
Hi, I am a Debian user and I have a problem with the wxt terminal. I've searched the Internet and found something. Debian has reportedly stopped the support for something necessary for the wxt terminal to work. I can view the plot with x11 terminal but the result is far from satisfactory. Do you know of any solution for this problem?
Thanks for a great page.
item.content:encoded:
Hi,
I am a Debian user and I have a problem with the wxt terminal. I’ve searched the Internet and found something. Debian has reportedly stopped the support for something necessary for the wxt terminal to work. I can view the plot with x11 terminal but the result is far from satisfactory. Do you know of any solution for this problem?

Thanks for a great page.

item.title: By: hagen
item.dc:creator: hagen
item.description: You can use the following recursion relationship: <pre class="prettyprint"> # Bessel functions (after Bronstein 2001, eq. 9.54a) besj2(x) = 2*1/x * besj1(x) - besj0(x) besj3(x) = 2*2/x * besj2(x) - besj1(x) </pre> See also <a href="https://github.com/Gnuplotting/wordpress-theme/blob/master/img/bessel.gnu" rel="nofollow">bessel.gnu</a>.
item.content:encoded:
You can use the following recursion relationship:

# Bessel functions (after Bronstein 2001, eq. 9.54a)
besj2(x) = 2*1/x * besj1(x) - besj0(x)
besj3(x) = 2*2/x * besj2(x) - besj1(x)

See also bessel.gnu.

item.title: By: Herman Jaramillo
item.dc:creator: Herman Jaramillo
item.description:
I love your pot with six Bessel functions. My "gnuplot" only find the one with 0 order and the one with order 1. How do I plot the higher order Bessel functions?
Thanks.
item.content:encoded:
I love your pot with six Bessel functions. My “gnuplot” only find the one with 0 order and the one with order 1. How do I plot the higher order Bessel functions?

Thanks.
